articles.headline: Belated Withdrawal From Risk
articles.snippet: Sometimes what appears to be best for every individual is bad for the group. Now is such a time in the banking business.
articles.abstract: Sometimes what appears to be best for every individual is bad for the group. Now is such a time in the banking business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sometimes what appears to be best for every individual is bad for the group. Now is such a time in the banking business.

articles.headline: Home Equity Frenzy Was a Bank Ad Come True
articles.snippet: Home equity loans, once seen as the borrowing of last resort, have grown a thousandfold since banks began spending billions of dollars to advertise them.
articles.abstract: Home equity loans, once seen as the borrowing of last resort, have grown a thousandfold since banks began spending billions of dollars to advertise them.

articles.headline: Bush Aides Say Russia Actions in Georgia Jeopardize Ties
articles.snippet: Russia’s military offensive in Georgia has punctuated a stark turnabout in the American view of Vladimir V. Putin, whom President Bush has called a friend.
articles.abstract: Russia’s military offensive in Georgia has punctuated a stark turnabout in the American view of Vladimir V. Putin, whom President Bush has called a friend.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia’s military offensive into Georgia has jolted the Bush administration’s relationship with Moscow, senior officials said Thursday, forcing a wholesale reassessment of American dealings with Russia and jeopardizing talks on everything from halting Iran’s nuclear ambitions to reducing strategic arsenals to cooperation on missiles defenses.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Lawyers’ Ties Hint at Extent of Hiding Edwards’s Affair
articles.snippet: John Edwards’s affair may have gone on longer than he admitted and the effort to conceal it may have been much more extensive than has been reported.
articles.abstract: John Edwards’s affair may have gone on longer than he admitted and the effort to conceal it may have been much more extensive than has been reported.
articles.lead_paragraph: As tabloid reports of a sex scandal threatened former Senator John Edwards’s presidential campaign last December on the eve of the Iowa caucuses, two lawyers surfaced with written statements that appeared to exonerate the candidate.
articles.byline: By Serge F. Kovaleski and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Russia’s Conflict Worries Wall Street
articles.snippet: As a military conflict between Russia and Georgia ends its first week, a number of big Wall Street banks are beginning to reassess the stability of their businesses in Russia.
articles.abstract: As a military conflict between Russia and Georgia ends its first week, a number of big Wall Street banks are beginning to reassess the stability of their businesses in Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Vladmir V. Putin of Russia wiped $6 billion in shareholder value from a Russian steel company last month with a few choice words, even risk-taking investors in Russia took notice.

articles.headline: T-Mobile to Offer First Phone With Google Software
articles.snippet: T-Mobile will be the first carrier to offer a mobile phone powered by Google’s Android software, according to people briefed on the company’s plans.
articles.abstract: T-Mobile will be the first carrier to offer a mobile phone powered by Google’s Android software, according to people briefed on the company’s plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: T-Mobile will be the first carrier to offer a mobile phone powered by Google’s Android software, according to people briefed on the company’s plans. The phone will be made by HTC, one of the largest makers of mobile phones in the world, and is expected to go on sale in the United States before Christmas, perhaps as early as October.
articles.byline: By Laura M. Holson and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: U.S. Is Pressuring Delphi Over Pension Obligations
articles.snippet: The government is trying to force Delphi to transfer more than $1.5 billion of unfunded pension obligations to General Motors by Sept. 30.
articles.abstract: The government is trying to force Delphi to transfer more than $1.5 billion of unfunded pension obligations to General Motors by Sept. 30.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government is trying to force Delphi to transfer more than $1.5 billion of unfunded pension obligations to General Motors by Sept. 30. It is warning Delphi, the big auto parts maker, that if it misses the deadline, it will have to contribute more than $2 billion to the fund, a burden that could dash any hopes of Delphi emerging from bankruptcy with its pension plan intact.

articles.headline: U.S. and Poland Set Missile Deal
articles.snippet: A deal to place a missile defense base on Polish territory angered Russia, but reflected alarm in countries like Poland about Moscow’s intentions.
articles.abstract: A deal to place a missile defense base on Polish territory angered Russia, but reflected alarm in countries like Poland about Moscow’s intentions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States and Poland reached a long-stalled deal on Thursday to place an American missile defense base on Polish territory, in the strongest reaction so far to Russia’s military operation in Georgia.
articles.byline: By Thom Shanker and Nicholas Kulish

articles.headline: Rice, in Georgia, Calls on Russia to Pull Out Now
articles.snippet: As the secretary of state tried to fix a loophole that Russia could use to justify its advance, Russian armor moved within 25 miles of Georgia’s capital, Tbilisi.
articles.abstract: As the secretary of state tried to fix a loophole that Russia could use to justify its advance, Russian armor moved within 25 miles of Georgia’s capital, Tbilisi.
articles.lead_paragraph: TBILISI, Georgia  The United States pressed on Friday for the immediate withdrawal of Russian forces in Georgia, as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice came here, not far from the front lines, to win the Georgian president’s approval for a redefined cease-fire. She pushed to close a loophole that Russia could use to justify its advance deep into Georgia.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Clifford J. Levy
